Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences Shenyang Liaoning 110016 China MXenes have emerged as a new kind of 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides and carbonitrides. Origined from the unique 2D structure with a luxuriant combination of elements, MXenes drive a series of the investigations related to energy storage and conversion, biometrics and sensing, lighting, purification and separation. For 2D layered MXene materials, the interspacing confined by the independent MXenes layers affords a distinct confinement space, which is similar to a nanoreactor that can be utilized for the storage of ions, nanoparticles, nanowires, and the materials with 2D or 3D structure. These fillings confined by MXene layers afford new opptunities for achieving improved properties and performance via complementary natural features, further the synergistic effect. Herein, we summarize the recent reports concerning with the confinded MXenes spacing and the fillings. The modification of interlayer distance lead by the intercalants were explored. We expect that our review may offer the route for a series of ongoing studies to address the MXenes. Graphical abstract The space confined by adjacent MXene layers was filled by the intercalants: H2O&solvents, ion, nanoparticles, polymers and structure materials, which gives rise to the change of interlayer environment and provides new functionality. Image, graphical abstract Keywords MXenes Interlayer distance Intercalation Structure Fillings 1 Introduction Transition metal carbides and nitrides (MXenes), a family of 2D layered structures, have rigorously emerged since the discovery of the first 2D layered Ti3C2T x MXene in 2011 [1]. Inspired by the initial synthesis methods and the new synthetic precursor of MAX, a variety of stable phases of >200 different MXenes have been determined and predicted on the basis of a combination of various transition metals (such as Ti, Mo, V, Cr, and their alloys) with C and N [2]. Attributed to their unusual electronic [3], mechanical [4] and optical properties [5], numerous exciting applications were underscored with praticularly great promise in electrodes of rechargeable batteries [6], supercapacitors [7], photocatalysts [8], catalysts [9], transparent conducting films [10], electromagnetic interference shielding [11] and sensors [12], adsorption agents for crude oil and heavy metals [13], and flexible high-strength composites [14]. Importantly, the 2D layered nature of MXenes can offer an interlayer space to hold a range of mono- and multi-valent cations, the polar organic molecules, and nanoparticels [15–17]. The space confined by the adjacent MXene layers can be also employed to encapsulate the nanowires [18], nanosheets [19] and other layered materials [20]. Moreover, the polymer can be filled in the space to form hybrids [21]. The interlayer distance, which plays a significant role for modifying the properties of MXenes, enables being expanded due to the interlayer space occupied by intercalants, or the required electrostatic balance. Controling the interlayer distances of MXenes has shown potential for enhancing various performance. This is particularly effecitve in energy stoarge [22], hetergeneous catalysis [13,23], and the fields related to ionic/electronic transport [24–26]. However, the discrete knowledge related on the confinement and fillings set a certain limitation for understanding the mechanistic interaction, which induces the structural and chemical changes in the interlayer of MXenes, and actives the fillings to funtionalize. In this account, in order to unify the intermodulation between the intercalants and the host of MXenes, we elaborated on the intercalants confined by MXene layers and sumed up the change of interlayer distance. The classification is initialized on the basis of H2O, ions, nanoparticles, 1D, 2D materials and 3D materials. Then it was utilized to categorize the confined substances. Subsequently, we emphasized the change of the interlayer distance related to the intercalants. To finalize, we provided a perspective on the methods to control the interlayer distance, and the challenges needed to confront. Our work may offer a chapter of the intercalated MXenes. 2 Basic principles of MXenes 2.1 Family As shown in Fig. 1 , origined from the MAX, the general formula of MXenes can be described as M n +1X n T x (n = 1–3), where M represents an early transition metal or binary metal combination (such as Mo2TiC2, Mo2Ti2C3 MXenes), and the X layers comprise C, N, or both. T x stands for the surface terminations (for example, −OH, −O and −F), which bond with the M after etching reaction [27]. Etching MAX to obtain MXenes was extended to more MAX phase ceramics, which comprise >60 family members [28–30]. As a continued product of MAX, the synthesis of new MXenes also required an ongoing discovery of more MAX members. 2.2 Synthesis To date, tremendous efforts have been made to develop synthetic methods of MXenes. It also extended the MXenes' range as well as clarification of the synthetic mechanism [31]. Generally, MXenes synthesis can be divided into two routes: one is top-down from MAX powders to MXene dispersions [32]; the other is bottom-up strategies from M and C atoms to form MXene layers [33]. It is known that the M−A bonds in MAX are more chemically active than the M−X bonds. As a consequence, it contributes to the selective etching of A-element layers from MAX. The first synthesis of multilayered Ti3C2T x based on the top-down strategy through the selective etching of M-A bond by hydrofluoric acid (HF) at room temperature. Therefore, the fluoride-based compounds (LiF, NaHF2, KHF2, NH4HF2, and molten fluoride salt) have been employed to effectively etch MAX [34,35]. This strategy faciliates for a high yield and easily scalable production of MXenes. In order to obtain single layers of MXenes, a delamination is needed. Various polar organic molecules (hydrazine, urea, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)), isopropylamine or large organic base molecules (tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH), choline hydroxide or n-butylamine), were pre-intercalated into the interlayer space of MXenes. Then it is followed by mechanical vibration or sonication to ulitimately form single or few layers MXenes [36–39]. In addition, electrochemical aid process can be introduced to enhance the etching and the delamination process [40]. Compared with the top-down synthesis, this strategy can produce large lateral sizes of high-quality MXene crystals with extremely low defects, disorder, and impurity. However, bottom-up approaches have numerous disadvantages including tedious synthesis protocols and low-efficiency production. Inspired by the early acquisition, bottom-up strategies like plasma-enhanced CVD with different metal substrates for the synthesis of high-quality MXene are expected to advance. 2.3 Structures The MXene unit is similar to their MAX precursors, as shown in Fig. 2 . The MXene monolayer sheet has a hexagonal lattice with sixfold symmetry. M atoms in MXenes are arranged in a close-packed structure and X atoms fill the octahedral interstitial sites. M is configured by six chemical bonds with the closest X atoms. This is due to the typical six-coordination observed in transition metal ions and leads to the formation of M n +1X n T x (n = 1–3) [41–44]. 2.4 Surface terminations The unique nature of MXenes has been underscored upon their development, as shown in Fig. 3 . The heterogeneous surface of MXenes synthesized using acidic-fluoride-containing solutions have a mixture of −OH, −O and −F terminations. Thus, it is usually denoted as M n +1X n T x , where T x represents the surface terminations [45]. The characterization of integrating EDX, XPS, NMR, and neutron scattering were employed to investigate the surface terminations and offer a quantitative analysis [46–48]. No matter for experimental and calculational sciences, the existence of surface terminations depends on the etching methods. Therefore, it leads to the dramatic impacts on stabilities, electronic structures and other physicochemical properties, consequently, results in the different performances for various applications [13,49–53]. Surface modification methods were utilized to tailor the distribution of the surface functional groups and introduce new species [48–52]. The difficulties lie in understanding the detailed bonding nature among surface species of bare MXene, the regulation rule between the surface metal species and surface functional groups, the interfacial interaction in MXenes originated from the surface terminations [54–58]. 2.5 Applications The rich chemistry and various range render the MXene structures promising for many applications [23,59–61], as shown in Fig. 4 . MXenes has attracted significant attention in energy storage. However, there are potentially other applications in which MXenes can outperform other materials. For example, Ti3C2T x MXene flexible films showed the highest ever reported electromagnetic interference shielding for a synthetic material of comparable thickness, higher than that of graphene and other carbon materials [62]. The ultizliation is invovled with the reinforcement for composites [63], water purification [64], catalysts in the chemical industry [65], gas- and biosensors [66], lubricants [67], photocatalysts [68], electrocatalysts and photothermal therapy [69]. 3 Intercalants confined by MXene layers 3.1 H2O and solvents 3.1.1 H2O In the synthesis process of MXene, an aqueous etching agent containing H2O was employed. EDX and XPS analysis found an increase of the O signal in MXenes; some of the present oxygen can account for the oxygen-contained surface terminations (O or OH), and some are confirmed from water physisorbed by the MXene layers [70]. When the MXenes were fabricated, water molecules were retained in the as-synthesized MXene. The remaining water can be divided into two types: one locates in the interparticle pores or surface-adsorbed H2O; other is confined by the MXene layers, called as the intercalated H2O, which can induce an expanded interlayer [71]. In addition, the MXenes can adsorpt H2O in the outside environment to spontaneously intercalate into the interlayer of MXenes. This has been reported for the V2CT x , Nb2CT x , Nb4C3T x and Ti2CT x MXenes. To study the effect of H2O confined by the adjacent MXene layers, three Ti3C2T x films at different moisture levels were examined by using X-ray diffraction (XRD). A-Film was dried at 140 °C, B-Film was dried at 70 °C, and C-Film was in a wet state. The (002) peak shifted to lower angles as A-B-C Film, which corresponds to an interlayer distance of 0.29 (A), 0.47 (B), 0.64 (C) nm, indicating that one layer of water molecules remained in the A-Film, two in B-Film, three in C-Film. In addition, the full width at half maximum (FWHM) become sharp upon the more water intercalated MXenes, which can be attributed to the higher degree of MXene layer alignment along the c-axis for the latter [72]. When a Ti3C2T x film was immersed in water, the interlayer distance increased from 1.34 to 1.72 nm, corresponding to a larger space of 0.72 nm between the two adjacent MXene sheets, which can be calculated by a subtraction of a monolayer MXene thickness (~ 1 nm), which can accommodate about two or even three layers of water molecules to transport rapidly [73]. Except for the independent water, some water molecules accompanied with the ions were confined by the interlayer of MXenes. In the aid of in situ XRD with variational relative humidity (RH) (Fig. 5 ), the interlayer distance change of the different hydrated metal ion intercalated Ti3C2T x MXenes was studied. The interlayer distance shows a discontinuous change in the interlayer distance, indicating the multilayered H2O confined by MXene layers. The different hydrated metal ion intercalated Ti3C2Tx MXenes show a different transition point of RH, which can be attributed that the water molecules separated from Ti3C2T x MXenes need to overcome the bonding force; the divalent cations have a sufficiently high driving force to form a bilayer H2O structure within the MXene interlayers at moderate humidity, whereas Li+ and Na+ require a higher RH due to their lower hydration energies, and K+ is unable to stabilize a bilayer [74]. The optimized hydration structures indicate the accommodation of larger amounts of water in MXene in the order of Li+>Na+>K+>Rb+. This trend is explained by the increasing hydration energy of cations as their bare ionic radii decrease [70]. Using neutron scattering combined with ab initio calculations to probe H2O intercalation, the data indicated that the interlayer distance can be maintained without the continuous layer of water molecules, which means an insignificant amount of water molecule confined MXene layers can obtain an expanded interlayer [75]. Water molecules become more ordered after metal ions intercalation, and ions strongly decrease the strength of the hydrogen bonds acting on intercalated water. Increasing the size of the metal ions enhances the ordering of water molecules [76]. Upon the more H2O molecules intercalated between the MXene interlayers, the more electrolyte ion of hydrogen ions can access to active sites of the Ti3C2T x electrode, giving a dramatic increase in gravimetric performance [71]. The calculated migration profiles of K+ and H+ using density functional theory, in the presence and absence of water, suggest that the intercalated water molecules stabilize the charged ions, facilitating their diffusion from 2D to 3D manifested by reduced activation barriers and movement pathways. Given the enhanced adsorption performance of hydrated and intercalated MXenes, and their promising applications for environmental remediation of heavy metal ions and dye molecules, further development of these materials for water purification is expected. These results have implications for understanding, controlling, and exploiting structural changes and H2O sorption in MXene films and powders utilized in applications involving ions, such as electrochemical capacitors, sensors, reverse osmosis membranes, and contaminant sorbents. 3.1.2 Solvent Inspired by H2O intercalated MXenes, other larger solvent molecules may be confined by the interlayer space between the two adjacent MXene layers. DMSO was used for the delamination of MXene, indicating that DMSO can be intercalated into the interlayer and weaken the interlaminar force [78]. The one-step ultrasonication-solvothermal method in different solvents including DMF, ethanol, and DMSO was employed to treat multilayered Ti3C2T x . It was confirmed that the solvothermal treatment using DMF as the solvent could render the largest interlayer space of 1.32 nm and the least oxidation effects on the MXene nanosheets, as shown in Fig. 6 [77]. DMF can also act as a weak reducing agent. Followed by the solvothermal process with DMF, most F and Cl impurities are removed and replaced by oxygen or hydroxyls. This behavior would force the Ti2CT x to restack and reorient [79]. The Li-ion intercalation process into the Ti3C2 MXene electrode relies on the choice of the electrolyte solvent (Fig. 7 ). Employing lithium bis (trifluoromethylsulfonyl) amine (LiTFSI) in propylene carbonate (PC) as an electrolyte, the Li ions confined by the interlayer space of the Ti3C2 MXene are found to be fully desolvated, which exhibits a charge-storage mechanism dominated by pseudocapacitive intercalation. Replacing the PC solvent with acetonitrile (ACN) or dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) results in a significant decrease of capacity owing to Li ions intercalated into MXenes with solvent molecules. The choice of confirmed solvent can control ionic transport and intercalation behavior with distinct evolutions in the interlayer spacing [80]. In addition, the MXene flakes exhibited different colloidal dispersion in various solvents. The results indicate that polar solvents disperse Ti3C2T x MXene better due to the MXene flakes with the polar termination groups on the surface [81]. No matter how the water or other solvent was confined by the adjacent MXene layers, the size and amount of intercalated molecules had an effect on the interlayer distance. When the solvent molecules intercalated independently, they tend to disorder due to the weak interaction with the MXene surface. However, when the solvent was inserted into MXenes accompanied by other ions, a strong bond may lead to a realignment of solvent molecules. To understand the state of MXenes in a different solvent can provide a guide for advances in many functional applications, including a wider range of MXene−polymer composites, inks for additive manufacturing, and more effective methods for producing films and 3D structures from MXene colloidal solutions. As a conclusion, the interlayer distance values of MXenes intercalated by intercalants related water or other solvents were provided in Table 1 . 3.2 Ion This section aims to summary these investigations related to the change interlayer environment and the intercalation chemistry of MXenes, and attempted to overview the relationship between the host and parasitic ions by a careful analysis of structure, surface terminations, and the evolution accompanied by the intercalation of ions. It has been confirmed that this approach is effective to employ ion to fill the interlayer space confined by two adjacent MXene layers to achieve a pillared structure. The interlayer spacing of MXenes can be fine-tuned via the creating pillared structures based on the intercalation of ions. By carefully selecting the types of different ions, a controlled interlayer spacing for targeted applications can be obtained. In this section, the papers on ion intercalated into MXenes were classified on the basis of the ionic species, such as alkali metal ion, non-metal ion and organic molecules. The statistics of the interlayer distance of the intercalated MXenes were also conducted to analyze the relationship between the intercalated ions and the interlayer distance. The intercalated ion confined within the interlayer of MXenes can also play a role of active sites for energy storage, catalysis, and detector. In addition, the intercalated ions can control the interlayer chemistry of MXenes. The surface terminations bond with the metal elements, critical on the properties of MXenes, can be precisely tuned. The investigation of ion intercalated MXenes would open new opportunities for the applications of MXenes. 3.2.1 Alkali metal ion The synthesis method of MXenes lies essentially at selectively removing A from MAX via using an etching agent, such as HF, LiF+HCl and NH4F. The surface terminations means a hydrophilic, primarily hydroxyl-terminated surface. Thus, it exhibited a negative zeta potential, affording the opportunity for some cations to intercalate into the interlayer of MXenes spontaneously. Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+ and Ca2+ ions can be thereof intercalated via immersing the MXenes into the salts, bases, or acids of cations [39,87]. Moreover, the intercalation behavior of some ions, notably Al3+, can be promoted by electrochemically driving. In order to confirm the cation intercalation, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy analysis of MXenes after ion intercalation was conducted to detect the characteristic elements of cations and anions. (002) peak as the response of c-axis was tracked for the change of the interlayer distance of the ion intercalated MXenes. 1 M LiOH, NaOH and KOH solutions were utilized to treat Ti3C2 MXenes. After pillaring, the XRD patterns reveal that (002) peak of Ti3C2T x shifted left, corresponding to an increase to 1.26 nm of the interlayer distance [88]. Ti3C2T x film electrodes in the electrolytes of LiCl, NaCl, and KCl were applied to the negative potential, and the intercalations behaviors of different cations were conducted. The larger interlayer distance of 1.305 nm (KCl), 1.313 nm (NaCl), and 1.344 nm (LiCl) can be obtained, respectively [89]. In order to study the size effect of intercalated ion, the first-principle density functional method found that an enhanced interaction between those ions with a larger effective ionic radius. Thus, it leads to the difficulty of ion intercalation [90]. To argue otherwise is a larger ion intercalated into the interlayer of MXenes can pillar a larger interlayer spacing. So the selective cation intercalation can increase the interlayer distance and expand the interlayer spacing, which can facilitate the intercalation behavior of the larger ions. However, a shrink on interlayer distance was found on the KOH treated V2CT x . The interlayer decreased from 0.95 to 0.938 nm due to the strong interactions for the intercalated K+ and MXene layers [91]. To study the effect of a cation's valence of the intercalated on MXenes, Ti3C2T x was immersed into Na2SO4, MgSO4 and Al2(SO4)3 solutions, respectively. The results clearly showed the (002) peaks of Ti3C2T x MXenes shifted left upon the ion intercalation with a higher valence. The Al3+ pre-intercalated Ti3C2T x MXenes, with an interlayer distance of 1.18 nm (Fig. 8 ). Since the Al3+ pre-intercalation provided a charge compensation during the charge/discharge process, it allows for more Li+ electrochemical intercalation reaction [16]. Except for the alkali metal ion, originated from the large specific surface area and wide layer spacing, MXenes can adsorb some metal ion (Pd2+ and Cu2+) confined between the interlayer of MXenes [15]. 3.2.2 Non-metal ion and organic molecules Compared with the metal ion, non-metal ion and organic molecules usually have a larger ionic radius. From a spatial point of view, the larger ions confined in the MXene layers can pillar a larger interlayer spacing. Once multilayered Ti3C2T x MXenes was immersed into N2H4•H2O (HM) solution, the interlayer distance increased from 0.975 to 1.274 nm. When the intercalator solution is the HM and dissolved in N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), an increased interlayer distance of 1.34 nm value can be reached due to a synergistic effect. DMSO and urea were intercalated into Ti3C2T x MXene and this leads an increased interlayer distance to 1.752 and 1.25 nm. In order to delaminate MXenes, these organic molecules were also employed to weaken the force between the adjacent MXene layers [36]. When Ti3C2 MXene was immersed in the cationic surfactant solution, attributed to the different lengths of hydrophobic alkyl chain (dodecyl trimethylammonium bromide (DTAB), tetradecyltrimethylammonium bromide (TTAB), CTAB, stearyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (STAB), dioctadecyldimethylammonium chloride (DDAC)), the cationic surfactant can be intercalated into the interlayer of Ti3C2 MXene via electrostatic interaction. The interlayer spacing of Ti3C2 MXene can be controlled according to the size of the intercalated pre-pillaring agent and can reach 2.708 nm (CTAB) compared with the original spacing of 0.977 nm. However, the intercalation needs more energy to overcome the increasing steric hindrance for cationic surfactants with a longer alkyl chain [92]. Tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) solution was used to obtain TMA+ cation-intercalated Ti3C2T x MXenes. The interlayer distance slightly increased from 1.09 to 1.42 nm after TMA+ intercalation. Hexadecylamine hydrochloride (HEXCl) and dodecylamine hydrochloride (DDACl) were used for ion–exchange reactions with the TMA+ cation-intercalated MXene. The interlayer distance further increased to 1.86 nm [22]. In addition, TBAOH and TPAOH can also lead to an increased interlayer distance of MXenes after the intercalation. Diazonium ions were introduced into the interlayer of Na+ intercalated Ti3C2T x MXenes, and the interlayer distance increased to 1.59 nm [93]. When Ti3C2T x MXene was treated by isopropyl amine solution, the (002) peak is shifted from 8.9° further to 6.4° and the interlayer spacing increased from 0.99 to 1.37 nm. The amino groups of R-NH3 +, which were produced during the hydrolyzation of isopropylamine in aqueous solution, promote the intercalation behavior via electrostatic force. Thus, it leads to the larger interlayer spacing [94]. Negatively charged Ti3C2 MXene caused adsorption of the cationic Azo-surfactant by the electrostatic interaction. The zeta potentials of Azo-MXene hybrid increased from −26.6 to −3.29 mV, indicating that the AzoTMA attached to the MXene nanosheets and resulted in a change of charge density. However, the (002) peak shifts right, indicating that the electrostatic modification leads to a decrease of interlayer distance [95]. In addition, the change of interlayer distance of MXenes induced by the ion-type intercalants were concluded in Table 2 . To ion intercalated into the interlayer of MXenes, the electrostatic interaction origined from the negative-charged MXenes was utilized to achieve the intercalation of the cation or positive-charged ions. However, for some ions with larger ionic radius and negative-charge, the resistance of intercalation limited the ion intercalation into MXenes. The development of new methods with the larger driving force for the intercalation was still needed. Therefore, several issues can be concentrated on: investigating the ion intercalation behavior, understanding the changed interlayer environment, and further controlling the interlayer structure and chemistry of MXenes. As a result, it can ultimately optimize the application for the intercalation electrodes for batteries, supercapacitors, and hybrid devices, for the ion permeability, for water purification or desalination and some sensors. 3.3 Nanoparticles Rich chemistry and wide range of structures make MXenes promising for building hybrid materials. Hybrid materials constructed via the MXenes and various nanoparticles have exhibited the potential for applications of electrochemical electrodes, electromagnetic interferce shielding, water purification/desalination, dye adsorption, catalyst, H2 generation, biosensors and photothermal therapy due to the two-fold merits. Synergistic effects based on the properties MXenes and nanoparticles were employed to enhance the performance of the nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the problem of re-stacked MXene flakes can be solved via the nanoparticles intercalated into the adjacent MXene layers. In this section, we concluded that the various nanoparticles can be confined by MXene layers. As a result, noble metal, metal alloy, oxide and sulfide nanoparticles and quantum dots with MXenes were introduced. The changed interlayer distance of MXenes, the synthesis methods, the structure of hybrids and the interactions were concerned. 3.3.1 Simple substance MXenes play a role of the promising platforms with versatile chemical reactivity and tunability for the facile design of supported intermetallic nanoparticles over a wide range of compositions and structures. Ag, Au, Pt, Pd and Rh: Noble metal nanoparticles have been intensively investigated as catalysts for a variety of organic catalytic reactions. It is well known that the structure and surface properties of the supports can significantly affect the catalytic activity, chemical and environmental stability, and recyclability of the catalysts. More importantly, besides having a unique 2D structure and a high metallic conductivity, MXenes have also large surface areas and an abundance of surface defects. That is, it facilitates the adsorption of metal precursors by electrostatic interactions. As a result, it serves as anchoring sites for the confined growth of highly dispersed metal nanoparticles, clusters, or even single atoms. Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets were employed for in situ grown of Pt nanoparticles (with sizes in the range of 2–8 nm) (Fig. 9 ). A larger interlayer distance from 0.93 to 1.38 nm was obtained after Pt growth. The 2D MXene nanosheets offer a matrix for loading Pt nanoparticles, leading to a high dispersion and a strong interaction of Pt-Ti3C2T x MXene interfaces. Abundantly exposed active sites with favorable electronic structures enhanced the efficiency of the HER [117,118]. The Pd@Ti3C2T x MXene nanocomposite was fabricated by in situ reduction of Pd(II) salt on the surface of Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets to form pseudo-spherical Pd nanoparticles with 2–6 nm size distributions. The (002) peak position remains unchanged after Pd loading, indicating no change of the interlayer distance [119]. Bimetallic oxide alloy nanoparticles of Pt and Pd or nanoclusters, which have the size of 2 − 3 nm and different metallic valence states, were deposited onto the Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets via solution plasma modification [120]. Au nanoparticles, with the tunable size of 5, 25, and 35 nm, were loaded via the self-reduction reactions of Ti3C2T x MXene material in a HAuCl4 solution. The (002) peak intensity of Ti3C2T x MXene at ~8.9° becomes weaker, which could be speculated to be the partial oxidation of the MXene sheet in the reduction reaction process of gold nanoparticles [121]. Upon mixing of Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets and Ag nanoparticles (8.5 ± 2.8 nm) aqueous dispersion solution, the electrostatic repulsion between Ag and Ti3C2T x MXene can provide the enhanced stability of the colloidal mixture without apparent agglomeration. A flexible Ti3C2T x /Ag NP hybrid film electrode was fabricated through filtering the mixture aqueous dispersion solution. In addition, the (002) peak intensity of Ti3C2T x becomes stronger and sharper with the increase of Ag content, suggesting that the introduced Ag nanoparticles increased the order of MXene nanosheets along the c direction [122]. Pt nanoparticles were loaded on the Ti3C2T x and Nb2CT x MXene via the incipient-wetness impregnation method. The average particle diameters of Pt nanoparticles are measured 6 ± 3.2 nm and 2.6 ± 0.7 nm for Pt/Ti3C2T x and Pt/Nb2CT x MXene, and further ordered Pt3Ti and Pt3Nb intermetallic compound nanoparticles are formed on the surface via reactive metal-support interactions on Pt/Ti3C2T x and Pt/Nb2CT x MXene, respectively [123]. Additionally, the stabilized Pt single-atom catalysts were loaded on the ultrathin two-dimensional Ti3− x C2T y MXene nanosheets via a simultaneous self-reduction stabilization process at room temperature. The single atoms stabilized onto the sites previously occupied by Ti, merited by a strong metal−carbon bonds with the Ti3− x C2T y MXene nanosheets. No XRD peaks corresponding to Pt NPs can be observed, and only the characteristic peaks of Ti3− x C2T y MXenes occured. It indicates that the introduction of Pt atoms did not significantly alter the structure of Ti3− x C2T y even though the valence state of Ti becomes slightly higher [124]. The Rh3+ ions in RhCl3 aqueous solution were captured through coordination with oxygen containing groups. Thus, Rh nanoparticles were formed on the Ti3C2T x MXene by using NaBH4 as a reducing agent. Rh nanoparticles have small particle sizes and enhanced metal dispersion of Rh species on the Ti3C2T x MXenes. In addition, the interlayer distance of Rh/Ti3C2T x MXenes hybrids increased, indicating Rh ions intercalated into MXenes and pillared the interlayer [125]. As a result, the MXenes/metal hybrid exhibit enhanced catalytic performances due to the increased exposure of active sites and the formation of strong electronic coupling effects. Such excellence renders MXenes highly promising as an ideal 2D matrix to support multifunctional metal catalysts. Sn, Co, Zn, Cu and metal alloy: Except for the noble metal nanoparticles, some metal and alloy nanoparticles employed MXenes as supports to overcome limitations origined from self's properties. Some ions can be captured by the surface chemical groups contained oxygen, such as hydroxyl and carboxyl. Sandwich-like nanostructured Sn/SnOx@Ti3C2 MXene composite was constructed by in-situ growth of Sn/SnOx nanoparticles on Ti3C2T x MXene by electrostatic attraction and liquid phase reduction. Sn/SnOx nanoparticles can play a role as pillars to avoid re-stacking of Ti3C2T x MXene flakes and enhance the longitudinal structural stability. Meanwhile, Ti3C2T x MXene flakes can limit the volume expansion and agglomeration of Sn/SnO x nanoparticles. This was confirmed that Sn/SnOx@Ti3C2 MXene composite can accelerate the Li-ion and electron transition [126]. The Cu/Ti3C2 MXene nanohybrid was fabricated via depositing Cu nanoparticles (with a size of 5 nm) onto 2D Ti3C2T x MXene based on a liquid-phase reduction approach. Upon hybridization with Cu nanoparticles, the interplanar distance estimated from (002) reflection increased from 1.29 to 1.51 nm, which could be ascribed to the intercalation of Cu nanoclusters into Ti3C2 layers. In addition, the electron transfer from Cu to Ti3C2T x MXene was found by XPS analysis. Interestingly, the electron transfer is independent of the loading amount of Cu nanoparticles [127]. Sandwich-like CoFe@Ti3C2T x composites were synthesized via the in-situ reduction in the aid of hydrazine. The broadening of the interlayer spacing is from 12.7 to 13.1 Å, indicating the intercalation of cobalt and iron ions and the following formation of CoFe nanosheets. Similar phenomenon has been also reported in CoNi-Ti3C2 MXene [128], MoSe2 [129], CuSe [130] and NiSe-Ti3C2 MXene [131]. Si: Owing to the high conductivity and good mechanical properties offered by MXenes, Ti3C2 MXene has the advantages of high conductivity (4600 S cm−1), excellent diffusion mobility for Li-ion (~10−10–10−9 cm2 s−1), and good mechanical properties. That is, it is a potentially ideal substrate for silicon. The Si@Ti3C2 MXene nanocomposite was prepared via mixing Si nanoparticles (40 nm) into multilayered Ti3C2 solution through ultrasonic treatment. Some silicon nanoparticles cover the surface of Ti3C2 MXene substrate and others were filled in the multilayer structure, which relieve the aggregation [132]. Employing the Ti3C2T x flakes as a matrix, MXene&Si flexible hybrid electrode was constructed via a filtration process of the mixture solution of Ti3C2T x flakes and Si nanoparticles. Smaller amorphous aggregates were observed in the MXene&Si hybrid electrode. The smaller fracture of Si occurred for the MXene&Si hybrid electrodes than pure Si electrodes. Then the produced nanosized amorphous Si particles were observed upon cyclic lithiation. A full lithiation behavior was found for the fracture of amorphous Si, which was usually deteriorated for electrochemical cycles [133]. In addition, the MXene inks were also utilized as a conductive binder of silicon electrodes, which enable fast charge transport and provide good mechanical reinforcement (Fig. 10 ) [134]. The utilization of 2D MXene nanosheets as a new matrix for Si electrodes is a solution for these challenges. The continuous network of MXene nanosheets not only provides sufficient electrical conductivity and free space for accommodating the volume change issue but also maintains the mechanical instability of Si. S: Li−S batteries suffer from low conductivities of sulfur and solid reduction products (Li2S2 and Li2S), severe side reactions between highly soluble intermediate polysulfides (Li2S n , 3 ≤ n ≤ 8) and the lithium anode, and a large volumetric expansion (~80%) from sulfur to Li2S [135]. Thus, it results in low specific capacity, fast capacity decay, and poor rate performance. Similar to the case of silicon, MXenes with a high number of open macropores and a large surface area. Such merits endow high S loading and facilitate ionic diffusion for fast lithiation/delithiation processes. The interlayer of MXenes could prevent the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides via further physically and chemically effects. In order to improve the loading of S, the multilayered Ti3C2T x MXene was treated by shaking in KOH solution and subsequently loaded with S via a melting−diffusion process to produce an S/Ti3C2 MXene hybrid (Fig. 11 ). The (002) diffraction peak of the hybrid exhibited no shift in XRD pattern. The hybrid electrode holds a lower charge-transfer resistance (R ct) and faster mass-transfer process, attributed to the Ti3C2T x nanosheet acted as a conductor agent [136]. In order to confine S, TiO2 hollow nanospheres were employed as sulfur hosts. Afterward, the S@TiO2 nanospheres were embedded into the interlayer of Ti2C MXene. S@TiO2/Ti2C composites exhibited enhanced electrochemical properties, which was attributed mainly to the synergistic effect between adsorption of Ti-S bonds with polysulfides, the encapsulation of TiO2 nanospheres for sulfur and the relaxation of nanolayered Ti2C for volumetric expansion of sulfur [137]. In addition, ultramicroporous carbon, with a uniform pore size of 0.55 nm, was employed as a host of small sulfur molecules (S2–4). And then, a 3D framework was constructed via embedding the S2–4/UMC particles within MXene flakes. The interlayer distance increased from 1.23 to 1.46 nm, indicating the S2–4/UMC composite was intercalated into the conductive network of MXenes. Utilizing MXene for a 3D conductive frame not only provided the fast electron transfer, but also it can take up the transfer of electrolyte ion [138]. Li2S/Ti3C2T x composite electrode was also prepared by ball milling and obtained a good performance in Li/S batteries. No matter what MXenes, as first or second-hand host of S, Li2S and small sulfur molecules, they rely on the high electron/ion transportability to improve the kinetics of Li-S electrochemical reaction system. It depends on the layered structure to confine the active materials in a specific space, which bypass the shuttle effect; resort to surface chemistry bonding the dissolved polysulfides [139]. Moreover, multilayered Ti3C2T x doped with S was successfully synthesized by direct sulfidation of Ti3C2T x using thiourea as the S source. An enhanced interlayer spacing from 0.956 to 0.998 nm after S doping was obtained, which can provide more space and active sites. Moreover, fluorine-containing functional groups were released during sulfidation [140]. 3.3.2 Oxide and sulfide In order to confine the oxide and sulfide by MXene layers, coprecipitation, hydrothermal method, atomic layer deposition and microwave heating methods were employed to achieve an in-situ growth of oxide and sulfide within interlayers [17,142,143]. Alternating filtration, spray coating and mixing, the methods based on electrostatic self-assembly were also utilized to construct the hybrid materials with MXenes [144–147]. The representative synthesis processes were shown in Fig. 12 . In addition, the MXenes can be also as a precursor to prepare MXene-derivatives via in-situ chemical conversion of the metal elements. Such as TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene [148], V2O5/V2CT x MXenes [149], NbO/Nb2CT x MXene [150]. These hybrids improved the performance based on the synergy effects which are utilized as the advantage origined from parts. The interface between MXenes and these oxides and sulfides exhibited potential for investigating, and the roles of MXenes in the hybrid need to understand. Addressing these problems, some reported results were concluded in this section. The Mn(NO3)2 solution was filtered with the mixed Ti3C2T x flakes suspension to a film. Thus, Mn ions are absorbed on the surface and into the interlamination of the Ti3C2 nanosheets via electrostatic self-assembly. A flexible MnO x -Ti3C2 MXene film was obtained after an annealing. The introduced MnO x nanoparticles can lead to an increased interlayer distance from 1.214 to 1.523 nm and prevent the restacking of the Ti3C2 nanosheets [151]. A RuO@Ti3C2T x MXene hybrid was prepared via mixing the anhydrous RuCl3 deoxygenated aqueous solution with Ti3C2T x MXene dispersed solution. After RuO2 were formed, the interlayer distance of hybrid increased from 1.40 to 1.45 nm [152]. MnO2 was introduced to the interlayer of Ti2CT x MXene by hydrothermal method. The interlayer distance of the hybrid increased from 0.992 to 1.26 nm [153]. SnO x nanosheets (5-nm-thick) were encapsulated in the interlayers of Ti3C2 MXene matrix by the in situ hydrothermal reaction to prepare SnO x @Ti3C2 MXene nanocomposites. The ultrathin SnOx nanosheets act as an interlayer spacer, which renders a larger interlayer distance of 1.16 nm. Meanwhile, it can also contribute to high capacities [154]. MXene flakes, as both current collector and conductive agent, were employed to construct a hybrid three-dimensional electrodes with CoFe2O4 nanoparticles via a two-step vacuum filtration process. The hybrid electrode shows a bilayer feature and enhanced Li+ storage ability (Fig. 13 ) [155]. In addition, ZnO [156], Sb2O3 [145], Mn3O4, Fe3O4 [147], LiFePO4, CoO, Li4Ti5O12 [157], BiOCl, NaTi2(PO4)3 [158], FeOOH [94], BiVO4, LiMn2O4, ZnFe2O4 [159] were confined by MXene layers and were employed to construct hybrid materials with MXenes. These hybrids obtained an enhanced performance in various fields. MXenes can be also used for building a hybrid with MoS2 via a solid state sintering technology, microwave heating or hydrothermal method [143,144,160–171]. Similar to the oxide confined by MXene layers, the MoS2 within the interlayer can pillar the adjacent MXene layers to obtain a larger interlayer space. The contact interface between nanoparticles was reduced instead of the contact with MXenes. The MoS2 nanoparticles were confined, and MXenes act as a media before the electron and ion transport to MoS2 [143,160,161,166,167,169–171]. Relying on the high conductivity and 2D layered structure of MXenes, the transportability was significantly enhanced. This enables improving the performance of applications related to energy storage and catalysis. To construct a hybrid with MXenes, the atomic interface contact between nanoparticles and MXenes layer determined the performance of hybrids. However, its synthesis is a challenge. Developing the new routes and improved the present methods can obtain an interface contact at atomic level, which may generate strong synergistic effects. 3.3.3 Quantum dots (QDs) Reducing the particle size to quantum dots (QDs), that are partly the result of the unusually high surface-to-volume ratios for these particles. The higher quantum confinement and small-size effect of QDs leads to unsaturated bond on surface and edges, proving more opportunity to connect with other atoms and obtain higher activity. However, an opposite is the severe agglomeration that leads to the declining performance. FeOOH QDs were anchored on the Ti3C2T x MXenes by in-situ growth approach. The (002) peaks after the loading of FeOOH QDs shifts left, indicating the increased interlayer distance from 0.98 to 1.10 nm. The XPS analysis implies the −F was removed, and the charge transfer happened between the MXenes and FeOOH QDs. They claimed the synergistic effect enhanced the charge transfer and accelerated the reaction kinetics for OER [172]. Ti3C2T x MXenes nanosheets were reported as a layered substrate of black phosphorus QDs. Van der Waals self-assembly was employed for the construction of the hybrid. MXenes can prevent the black phosphorus QDs aggregation and enhance electronic conductivity. Black phosphorus QDs can act as a pillar to isolate the MXene flakes. After hybridzation with black phosphorus QDs, the interlayer distance increased from 1.30 to 1.49 nm [173]. In addition, MoS2 QDs [174], SnO2 QDs [175] and TiO2 QDs [176] were reported that confined by MXene layers. The related nanoparticles confined by the MXene interlayers were concluded in Table 3 . 3.4 Nanowires Effective structure design routes have been confirmed to be of great significance for the MXene materials. Employing CNTs, cellulose, metal nanowires, nylon, nanobelt to hybridize with MXenes, these one-dimensional (1D) nanomaterials can be encapsulated in the space confined by the two adjacent MXene layers, and pillared the MXenes to obtain a larger interlayer distance, and prevent the aggregation and restack during self-assembly of the dispersed MXene flakes due to the strong interplanar van der Waals interactions. These introduced 1D nanomaterials contacted with the MXene flakes, are similar to a bridge between these MXene flakes which are close but not touching, as shown in Fig. 14 . Relying on the framework, an increased mechanical strength and toughness performance of the hybrids of MXenes can be reached. Open or porous architectures origined from this hybrid can provide a larger interspace and high-speed channel for ions, electrons and other medium. The strategy introduced 1D materials have shown highly effective for achieving optimized performance for various applications. MWCNT was introduced as interlayer support of Ti3C2T x MXenes, and the interlayer distance increased from 2.5 to 4.4 nm, which offers fast ion transport paths. Contributed by the hybrid architecture electrode, the micro-supercapacitors was offered with an excellent frequency response and a higher capacitance density [216]. In addition, the CNTs&Ti3C2T x MXenes hybrids were employed for the improved performance for lithium ion batteries, supercapacitor, electromagnetic wave absorption, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding and strain sensor. These configurations based CNTs change the overlapping areas of MXene flakes and construct some interconnecting channels, and allow a controlled initial tunneling interlayer distances of MXene layers and interspace between neighboring overlapped MXene flakes. In order to enhance the mechanical properties, ultrathin and highly flexible Ti3C2T x MXene/cellulose nanofiber composite paper with a nacre-like lamellar structure is fabricated via a vacuum-filtration-induced self-assembly process. Contributed by the interaction between cellulose nanofiber and Ti3C2T x MXene flakes, high tensile strength and fracture strain, as well as excellent folding endurance were obtained [217]. To utilize the layer by layer electrostatic self-assembly in the aid of vacuum filtration, WO3 nanorods, Kevlar nanofiber were introduced into MXene layers [218]. Taking advantage of the surface chemical states of MXenes, in situ growth nanowires can achieve a strong interface contact with MXenes. The integration may lead to a higher electronic conductivity and an enhanced structural stability. The sandwich-like Na0.23TiO2/Ti3C2 composites were prepared by in situ transition of the surface Ti atoms via NaOH. The electrically connecting interfaces facilitated the ionic and electronic transports by the 3D sandwichlike architecture. In addition, this design can relieve the strain of the electrode upon cycling [219]. Similar methods were employed to obtain TiO2 nanowires/ Ti3C2 MXene composite based on the oxidation in KOH solution [220]. Integration of 1D nanostructured unit into 2D MXenes constructed a 3D architecture, exhibited a virtual mode of structural analogy similar to the realistic architectural design. The hybridization of the materials with different dimensions exhibited potential for materials design for different application scenarios. The 1D materials confined by MXene interlayer were concluded in Table 4 . 3.5 Other layered materials Thanks to the combination of hydrophilic surface, metallic conductivity and rich surface chemistries, MXenes offer the possibility to designing well-defined heterostructures with other 2D layered materials. It is an effective way to solve these problems that are natural restacking tendency, unsatisfied electrical conductance, and necessary mechanical property. Taking advantage of synergistically chemical, electronic coupling and interconnected porous network origined from the heterogeneous structure constructed by two 2D layer materials, the full potential of these layered materials can be explored. The delaminated Ti3C2T x MXene/cobalt-aluminum layered double hydroxide composites were constructed by a layer-by-layer self-assembly driven by electrostatic interaction. The obtained Ti3C2T x MXene/cobalt-aluminum layered double hydroxide heterostructure exhibited a high electron conductivity of Ti3C2T x and a high electrochemical activity of CoAl-LDH. Thus, it results in effectively improving the electrochemical reactivity and accelerating the kinetics of Faraday reaction in alkaline hybrid batteries [20]. Ti3C2T x MXene and Ni-Co LDH hybrids were fabricated by an electrodeposition technique [228]. Hierarchical FeNi-LDH/Ti3C2-MXene nanohybrids were fabricated by ionic hetero-assembly of interconnected porous network of FeNi-LDH nanoplates on Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets. So, it exhibited the excellent structural stability, electrical properties and interfacial junction [229]. Unique layered Ti3C2/Ni−Co−Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) heterostructures alternatively stacked with molecular-level nanosheets were synthesized by a facile liquid-phase co-feeding and electrostatic attraction process. The molecular-level Ti3C2/Ni−Co−Al-LDH heterostructures possessing the merits of both conductive and pseudocapacitive components can show greatly enhanced dynamic behavior in Faradaic reaction, which is significant for obtaining a high power density [230]. In addition, the layered carbon materials, such as graphene [33,231,232], C3N4 [19,233,234], were employed to construct MXene/layered carbon materials composite through alternating electrospray, self-assembly method, self-convergence process (Table 5 ). The carbon materials confined by MXene layers could prevent the restacking of MXene layers and expand their interlayer space, thus increasing the active sites, shortening the ion diffusion path, and promoting the electrolyte transport. Not just for energy storage, these heterostructure materials have also shown potential in the applications of catalysis, photodetectors, and solvent permeation and molecule separation. It is a great challenge and of fundamental importance to rationally design molecular-scale MXenes and other layer materials to realize the heterostructures. These molecule-level heterostructures would make sufficient use of the high conductivity, rich surface chemistry and mechanical property of MXenes due to the face-to-face contact of the two-layered materials. As a result, the heterostructure design strategy will pave the way for energy-storage, optoelectronics, catalysis, sensing and other fields. 3.6 Polymer MXenes, with high conductivity, reactive surface chemistry and hydrophilicity, can offer a unique platform for the introduction of a polymer. Design the MXene hybrid materials via the incorporation of polymers into MXene layers, is a promising route for obtaining a controlled morphology, thickness, conductivity, and mechanical strength hybrid. Polymer chains can pillar and result in an expanded interlayer of the Ti3C2T x MXene layers, enhanced mechanism properties, which may extend the applications of MXenes by manufacturing functional hybrid materials with useful chemical, physical, mechanical, and electrochemical properties. The organic-inorganic PFD with different lateral chain functionalities were introduced for constructing the polymer&Ti3C2T x MXene hybrids. The polymers bearing charged nitrogen-containing groups expanded the interlayer spacing of Ti3C2T x MXene layers from 1.22 to 1.65 nm, superior to nonpolar and polar but neutral polymers, indicating that a strong chemical interaction between the charged ends of the polymers and MXene surfaces. The polymer&Ti3C2T x MXene hybrids afford the improved gravimetric/volumetric capacitance, and excellent rate performance. This can be attributed to the improved accessibility of the MXene surface to protons due to the pillaring of the Ti3C2T x layers by polymer chains [239]. MXene sheets are modified by in situ polymerized PPy to form stable inks for the conformal coating of PET textile. The presence of PPy enhances the interfacial interactions between the MXene sheets and the textile fibers and improves the EMI shielding performances [240]. Porous Ti2CT x MXene/poly (vinyl alcohol) (PVA) composite foams were obtained via the freeze-drying approach. This improved the impedance matching origined from the porous structures, internal reflection, and polarization effect, which can improve absorption efficiency and superior EMI shielding performance [241]. EDOT, PES, PDA, PANI, PPy, PVA, PAA and PAN were introduced into MXenes to construct the hybrid materials with well-defined properties for energy storage applications and beyond. The increased interlayer distance values were concluded as shown in Table 6 . MXenes, as ideal nanosheets for fabricating multifunctional and flexible textiles on the basis of their superb intrinsic electrical conductivity, tunable surface chemistry, and layered structure, aggregate through van der Waals interactions in polymer matrices. It is necessary to gain a fundamental understanding of the interaction of polymers with MXene surfaces. 3.7 3D structure materials Meanwhile, some materials with 3D structures were introduced into the MXene layers, and pillar the space confined by the MXene flakes. With the help of the 3D structure materials, make the 2D MXenes form a 3D architecture, the distance between two layers of MXene increased significantly. This may provide a new strategy to solve the restack issues of 2D MXenes and increase the ionic transport in the hybrids. Meanwhile, the MXenes can provide a high-speed electronic conductivity for the 3D structure materials. 3D porous MXene−rGO hybrid films were fabricated via the process of electrolyte assisted self-assembly, and vacuum filtration, followed by moderate postprocessing. The introduced GO supported the dense stacked MXene flakes to a 3D porous hybrids. The hybrids exhibited an enhanced diffusion of electrolyte ions and a high electrical conductivity. Relying on the synergistic effect of the high electronic conductivity and fast ionic transport, the 3D structure hybrid electrodes exhibit an outstanding rate capability and excellent cycle performance in LIBs [255]. Due to the 2D layered structure, excellent mechanism and high conductivity, MXene can play a multifunctional role in the electrode, including as a binder, a flexible backbone, a conductive additive, and an additional active material. The activated carbon particles were encapsulated between the MXene flakes to eliminate the need for insulative polymer binders. The synergetic effect origined from the MXene flakes and the activated carbon hybrids, which constructs a 3D conductive network and enlarges the interlayer space between the MXene layers, greatly enhanced the electrode capacitance and rate capability [256]. In order to overcome the poor electronic conductivity and low chemical stability of 2D metal-porphyrin frameworks (MPFs), highly conductive MXene nanosheets were intercalated into MPFs via a vacuum-assisted filtration technology. The alternant insertion of MXene and MPFs with hydrogen bond connection affords 3D interconnected “MPFs-to-MXene-to-MPFs” conductive networks. Depending on the porous structure, the transmission path in hybrids was shortened, which improves the ionic and electronic transportability. Meanwhile, MXene/MPFs hybrid electrodes may restrain the serious volume changes arisen from the phase separation, structural collapse upon the cycles. and increase the rate and cycle performance, even maintaining a great electrode structural integrity under bending and folding [257]. MXene-based sponge hybrids, constructed via dipping MXene dispersions to coat the sponge, MXene flakes uniformly coated on the 3D skeleton of sponge. The hybrids were applied in the piezoresistive sensor with insulating Polyvinyl Alcohol (PVA) nanowires as a spacer. The sensor based on MXene-sponge exhibited high sensitivity with a low detection limit of 9 Pa, a rapid response time of 138 ms, and an outstanding durability. This sensor can be used for the monitor of the human physiological signal [258]. Carambola-like MXene/polypyrrole hybrids with 3D structures were fabricated by one-step co-electrodeposition method. 2D layered Ti3C2T x -MXene flakes offered the surface and the interlayer space to pyrrole monomer radical cations for polymerize reaction. The 3D structure hybrids improved the electron transfer and ionic diffusion, consequently, the MXene/PPy composite film electrodes exhibited an outstanding electrochemical performance [259]. By in situ hybridized 2D cobalt 1,4-benzene dicarboxylate (CoBDC) with Ti3C2T x MXene flakes in the aid of an interdiffusion reaction, Ti3C2T x MXene/ CoBDC MOF hybrid was obtained. Thanks to the porous structure and large active surface area of the CoBDC layers, the electrically conductive and hydrophilic surface of Ti3C2Tx flakes, the higher ionic and electronic conductivities were obtained. In addition, the well-defined Ti3C2Tx−CoBDC interface provided a high-speed channel for the access of aqueous electrolyte to the catalytically active CoBDC surfaces (Fig. 15 ) [254]. Sodium alginate was employed as interlayer spacer for Ti3C2T x MXene flakes, which not only avoid the restacking of lamella structure but also serve as building blocks for the sponge-like structure. Followed by calcium exchange, MXene/calcium alginate aerogel with sponge-like structure was fabricated via divalent metal ion induced crosslinking, vacuum-assisted-filtration induced self-assembly, and freeze-drying. Owing to the sponge-like structure, Ti3C2T x /CA aerogel film presents excellent EMI shielding effectiveness. This is correlated with the fact that the dissipation of incident electromagnetic waves was reduced by multireflection and scattering [260]. The 3D materials confined by MXene interlayer were concluded in Table 7 . For the MXene based hybrids with 3D structure, the heterostructure interfaces between the two components constructed countless interspace, which allowed the fast charge and ion transfer during the electrocatalytic, electrode processes. Consequently, the 3D hybrids may provide an efficient strategy to solve the issue of poor ionic transport in energy storage electrodes and enhance the catalytic performance, further inspiring the potential of MXene materials. 4 Conclusions and perspective The aim of this account is to introduce the intercalants and the space confined by MXene layers, and provide the fundamental information on the change of interlayer distance given rise to the intercalants. We proposed that the classificated intercalants were incorporated into the space confined by MXene layers. These fillings confined by the adjacent MXene nanosheets prevent the stack and pillar an interspacing, which can be used for the reaction related on ions or others. 2D layered feature of MXenes is presented via an architecture design. The interaction between the intercalants and confined spaces induced the hybrids to offer the complementary features. It can be further synergistic to realize the enhanced performance. The emergence of intercalated MXenes and MXene-based hybrids has given rise to a wide range of application. It consists of superb performance of (1) energy storage applications, such as electrodes in rechargeable lithium- and others-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, and supercapacitors; (2) energy conversion includes photo-, electro- and chemical catalysis, electromagnetic interference shielding, reinforcement for composites, water purification, gas- and biosensors, and lubrication. To further understand the intermodulation mechanism between the confined space and the fillings, and achieve the precise tuning of MXenes, there are some challenges: the introduced intercalants into the interlayer space of MXenes remain to be investigated and understood for the basic mechanism, ranging from the spacing effect, static electricity to the surface chemistry. In addition, for the improved MXene use, the interlayer structure and environment should be analyzed by using advanced characterization techniques, especially, the atomic level observation methods. In particular, the location of the surface terminations should be confirmed. Not only the single atom/ion confined by the interlayer spacing should be investigated, but also the interaction among multi-ions within the interlayer should be explored. By using calculation/simulation methods, the ionic and electronic transport paths may be predicted theoretically. Definitely, these problems are very complicated. Relying on the systematic investigation combined with advanced analysis approaches, we believe an essential clarification of MXenes structure, interlayer environment, and the fillings must be obtained via: to monitor the change of interlayer distance induced by the fillings; to trace the characteristic element of intercalants and analyze the changes; to connect the chemical state variation of the metal and surface terminations of MXenes. Moreover, the in-situ characterization technology can be employed to achieve the dynamic changing model combined with the calculation simulation. The investigations of the space confined by MXene layers may open new avenues for understanding the MXenes and obtaining enhanced multifunctional performance. coredata.dc:description: MXenes have emerged as a new kind of 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides and carbonitrides. Origined from the unique 2D structure with a luxuriant combination of elements, MXenes drive a series of the investigations related to energy storage and conversion, biometrics and sensing, lighting, purification and separation. For 2D layered MXene materials, the interspacing confined by the independent MXenes layers affords a distinct confinement space, which is similar to a nanoreactor that can be utilized for the storage of ions, nanoparticles, nanowires, and the materials with 2D or 3D structure. These fillings confined by MXene layers afford new opptunities for achieving improved properties and performance via complementary natural features, further the synergistic effect. Herein, we summarize the recent reports concerning with the confinded MXenes spacing and the fillings. The modification of interlayer distance lead by the intercalants were explored. We expect that our review may offer the route for a series of ongoing studies to address the MXenes.
